question.title: Win or Lose
question.content:
You and your friends are playing a turn-based game. You will make the first move. Initially, you have an integer ‘N’. On each player’s turn, that player makes a move consisting of two steps.

1) Choose an integer ‘i’ such that 0 < ‘i’ < ‘N’ and ‘N’ is divisible by ‘i’.
2) Update number ‘N’ to ‘N - i’.

If a player cannot make a move, they lose the game.

You are given the initial number ‘N’. You have to print “YES” if you win the game; otherwise, print “NO”.

For example:

If the number ‘N’ = 6 and you select ‘i’ to be 2, then the new number ‘N’ will be 6 - 2 = 4.
Input Format-
First-line contains ‘T’, denoting the number of Test cases.
For each Test case:
The first line contains an integer, ‘N’, denoting the starting number.
Output Format-
For each test case, you have to print “YES” if you win the game; otherwise, print “NO”.
Note :
You don’t need to print anything. It has already been taken care of. Just implement the given function.
Constraints -
1 <= ‘T’ <= 5000
1 <= ‘N’ <= 10^9

Time Limit: 1 sec
Sample Input-1
2
2
3
Sample Output-1
YES
NO
Explanation for Sample Input 1:
For test case 1:
    You can choose only ‘1’; the new number becomes 2 - 1 = 1.
    Your friend can’t make any move. Hence you win the game.
For test case 2:
    You can choose only ‘1’; the new number becomes 3 - 1 = 2.
    Your friend can choose only ‘1’; the new number becomes 2 - 1 = 1.
You can’t make any move. Hence you lose the game.
Sample Input -2
2
13
16
Sample Output -2
NO
YES

rephrased.body: You and a friend are playing a turn-based game. You go first. The game starts with an integer, N. On each turn, a player chooses an integer 'i' such that 0 < 'i' < N and N is divisible by 'i', then updates N to N - i. The player who cannot make a move loses. Given the initial value of N, determine if you can win the game.

testcases.explanation:
Test Case 1: N = 2. You choose i = 1. N becomes 1. Your friend has no valid moves and loses. You win.
Test Case 2: N = 3. You choose i = 1. N becomes 2. Your friend chooses i = 1. N becomes 1. You have no valid moves and lose.

Test Case 1: N = 13. You choose i = 1. N becomes 12. Friend chooses i=1,N=11. You choose i=1,N=10. Friend chooses i=1,N=9.You choose i=1,N=8. Friend chooses i=1,N=7. You choose i=1,N=6. Friend chooses i=1,N=5. You choose i=1,N=4. Friend chooses i=1, N=3. You choose i=1, N=2. Friend chooses i=1,N=1. You loose.
Test Case 2: N = 16. You can win this game.

hints: How does the win or loss depend on the previous number?
How does the win or loss depend on the parity of the number?
